description: Bridge Axiom Templates for Ecological-Financial Translation

changelog.changes: Expanded axiom set from 16 to 35 for mechanism reasoning support. Added 19 new axioms: BA-017 through BA-035 covering carbon domain (6), coastal protection (4), tourism/fisheries (3), biodiversity/finance (4), and cross-cutting (2). Supports Concept node traversal in v4 intelligence upgrade.

Added 4 blue carbon axioms BA-013 through BA-016: seagrass carbon sequestration rate, carbon stock to credit value, habitat loss carbon emission, and MPA protection carbon permanence. All coefficients research-grounded with verified DOIs.

Added uncertainty quantification to all axiom coefficients: ci_low, ci_high, distribution, study_sample_size, effect_size_type, extraction_note. BA-001 through BA-004 have research-grounded bounds; BA-005 through BA-012 flagged as estimated_uncertainty where literature bounds unavailable.
BA-001: Corrected primary DOI (was pointing to wrong paper), updated coefficients with verified 2024 WTP model source (Marcos-Castillo et al.); fixed secondary DOI typo (9207->9198z for Uyarra 2009)

axioms.name: mpa_biomass_dive_tourism_value
axioms.description: Fish biomass increases in MPAs drive increased diver willingness-to-pay and tourism revenue
axioms.pattern: IF full_protection(Site) THEN biomass_increase(Site, 113%) AND wtp_increase(Site, 84%) AND revenue_contribution(biomass, 47%)

wtp_increase_for_biomass_max_percent.extraction_note: 84% is stated as upper bound ('up to 84%'); lower bound estimated from methodology (random forest on 27,609 dive sites). Main text, Results section.

biomass_contribution_to_revenue_percent.extraction_note: 47% stated as point estimate, no CI in main text. Bounds estimated from model decomposition (biomass 47% + biodiversity 49% + MPA name 4% = 100%).

average_biomass_increase_full_protection.extraction_note: Mean 113% with std dev 133% from global analysis. CI estimated as mean +/- 1 std dev, clamped at 50% lower bound.

global_additional_revenue_usd_millions.extraction_note: $616M point estimate, no CI in paper. Bounds estimated at +/-35% based on input parameter sensitivity.

tourism_value_per_ha_yr_median_usd.extraction_note: Median dive tourism value per ha per year (~$350/ha/yr) for Indo-Pacific reef sites, derived from Cabral et al. 2025 global bioeconomic model ($616M additional revenue across major MPA reef areas). Consistent with WTP meta-analysis range $250-500/ha/yr for high-value tropical reefs.

sources.citation: Cabral RB et al. 2025. Scientific Reports
sources.finding: Global bioeconomic model: divers willing to pay up to 84% more for biomass increases; 47% of economic improvements from biomass gains

sources.citation: Uyarra MC et al. 2009. Environmental Management
sources.finding: Divers select destinations based on marine life quality and quantity

caveats: Willingness-to-pay varies by diver experience and destination
Assumes existing dive tourism infrastructure
Effect magnitude depends on baseline conditions
MPA name effect provides immediate value before biological recovery
84% WTP figure is an upper bound, not a mean estimate

example_calculation.interpretation: Full protection -> 113% biomass increase -> up to 84% higher WTP -> 47% of total revenue improvement

axioms.methodology_note: Based on willingness-to-pay demand curve estimation, not simple linear elasticity

axioms.name: notake_mpa_biomass_multiplier
axioms.description: No-take MPAs accumulate fish biomass relative to unprotected areas
axioms.pattern: IF mpa_type(Site, 'no_take') AND enforced(Site, TRUE) AND age_years(Site, N) THEN biomass_ratio(Site, f(N))

biomass_ratio_vs_unprotected.extraction_note: Global meta-analysis of 82 MPA studies. 95% CI [4.5, 8.9]. Only 18/82 provided temporal data for trend detection.

biomass_ratio_vs_partial_protection.extraction_note: Derived from same meta-analysis. CI estimated proportionally from full protection ratio CI.

recovery_rate_per_year.extraction_note: Recovery rate from temporal subset (18 studies). Bounds estimated from study-to-study variation.

sources.citation: Hopf JK et al. 2024. Ecological Applications
sources.finding: Global meta-analysis of no-take MPA effectiveness: 82 studies, mean biomass ratio 6.70x

sources.citation: Edgar GJ et al. 2014. Nature
sources.finding: NEOLI criteria determine MPA conservation outcomes

example_calculation.interpretation: 10-year-old enforced no-take reserve has 670% of unprotected biomass

axioms.name: sea_otter_kelp_carbon_cascade
axioms.description: Sea otter presence drives trophic cascade increasing kelp carbon storage
axioms.pattern: IF otter_presence(Site, TRUE) THEN carbon_storage_multiplier(Site, 12) AND carbon_value_usd(Site, V)

npp_with_otters_g_c_m2_yr.extraction_note: Range 313-900 from 40 years of kelp data, Vancouver Island to Aleutians. Midpoint 607 used as mode.

npp_without_otters_g_c_m2_yr.extraction_note: Range 25-70 from same dataset. Midpoint 48 used as mode.

npp_multiplier.extraction_note: Computed from NPP range endpoints: min ratio 313/70=4.5, max ratio 900/25=36. Central estimate 12x.

carbon_storage_increase_tg.extraction_note: Explicit range 4.4-8.7 Tg C from paper. Midpoint 6.55 as mode.

carbon_value_usd_million.extraction_note: Explicit range $205-408M at $47/tonne (2012 European Carbon Exchange price). Midpoint $307M as mode.

sources.citation: Wilmers CC et al. 2012. Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment
sources.finding: Sea otters increase kelp carbon storage worth $205-408M (40 years of data, Vancouver Island to Aleutians)

context_dependency.reference: Selden et al. 2024 PNAS - muted cascade at San Nicolas Island

axioms.name: coral_reef_flood_protection
axioms.description: Coral reef structural integrity reduces coastal flood damages
axioms.pattern: IF reef_condition(Site, C) AND reef_area_km2(Site, A) THEN flood_protection_value_usd(Site, f(C, A))

global_flood_protection_value_usd_billio.extraction_note: 71,000 km reef coastline at 2km resolution (~35,500 profiles). No explicit CI in paper; ~10% sensitivity from friction/wave parameters. 100-year storm scenario.

healthy_reef.extraction_note: 97% from Ferrario et al. 2014 meta-analysis of reef wave attenuation. Bounds from study variation.

degraded_reef.extraction_note: Estimated from reef structural complexity loss scenarios. Wider bounds due to variable degradation states.

damage_increase_without_reefs_percent.extraction_note: 91% for 100-year storms. Sensitivity: 10% change in run-up from friction parameters, 2% per 10cm depth. Bounds estimated.

protection_value_per_ha_yr_median_usd.extraction_note: Coastal flood protection value per ha per year for healthy coral reef sites. Derived from Beck et al. 2018 ($272B/yr global, Beck et al. 2019 UNEP per-site analysis) and regional avoided-damage transfer. Consistent with ESV transfer literature range $800-1,500/ha/yr for tropical coastal protection.

sources.citation: Beck MW et al. 2018. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Coral reefs provide $272B/year in global flood protection for 100-year storms (71,000 km coastline)

axioms.name: mangrove_flood_protection
axioms.description: Mangrove extent and width provide coastal flood protection
axioms.pattern: IF mangrove_area_ha(Site, A) THEN flood_protection_value_usd_yr(Site, A * V_ha)

global_protection_value_usd_billion_yr.extraction_note: Point estimate from paper; bounds estimated at +/-20% based on typical ESV transfer error.

storm_surge_decay_rate_cm_per_km.extraction_note: Bounds estimated from variation in mangrove density and structure.

value_per_ha_yr_mean_usd.extraction_note: Mean $4,185, median $239, range $100-$57,000 from meta-analysis. Extreme right skew indicates lognormal.

sources.citation: Menendez P et al. 2020. Scientific Reports
sources.finding: Mangroves provide >$65B/year global flood protection

sources.citation: Salem ME & Mercer DE. 2012. Sustainability
sources.finding: Meta-analysis of mangrove economic values

axioms.name: mangrove_fisheries_production
axioms.description: Mangrove extent correlates with adjacent fisheries catches
axioms.pattern: IF mangrove_fringe_ha(Site, A) THEN fisheries_value_usd_yr(Site, A * V_ha)

value_per_ha_yr_median_usd.extraction_note: Median value from Gulf of California study. Bounds estimated at +/-60% from cross-site variation.

species_proportion_mangrove_dependent.extraction_note: Proportion of species dependent on mangroves. Bounds estimated from regional variation.

sources.citation: Aburto-Oropeza O et al. 2008. PNAS
sources.finding: Mangroves in Gulf of California increase fishery yields

sources.citation: Carrasquilla-Henao M et al. 2025. Comms Earth & Environ
sources.finding: Mangroves support 700B juvenile fish/invertebrates annually

axioms.name: mangrove_carbon_stock
axioms.description: Mangrove ecosystems store exceptional carbon per hectare
axioms.pattern: IF mangrove_condition(Site, C) THEN carbon_stock_mg_ha(Site, f(C))

undisturbed_mg_c_ha.extraction_note: From Donato et al. 2011. Bounds estimated at +/-20% from site-level variation in Indo-Pacific mangroves.

sequestration_rate_g_c_m2_yr.extraction_note: From Murdiyarso et al. 2023. Bounds estimated from cross-site variation in Indonesian mangroves.

axioms.comparison: 4x more carbon than most tropical forests

sources.citation: Donato DC et al. 2011. Nature Geoscience
sources.finding: Mangroves among most carbon-rich forests in tropics

sources.citation: Murdiyarso D et al. 2023. Carbon Balance Management
sources.finding: Indonesian mangrove emission factors by condition

axioms.name: seagrass_carbon_credit_value
axioms.description: Seagrass conservation and restoration generate carbon credit revenue
axioms.pattern: IF seagrass_project_type(Site, T) AND area_ha(Site, A) THEN carbon_revenue_usd_10yr(Site, f(T, A))

carbon_credit_range_usd_per_ha.extraction_note: Range $198-$15,337/ha from Duarte et al. 2025. Midpoint $7,768 as central estimate. Extreme range reflects project type variation.

net_offset_t_co2e_ha_yr.extraction_note: From Oreska et al. 2020. Bounds estimated at +/-50% from site-level variation.

sources.citation: Duarte CM et al. 2025. npj Ocean Sustainability
sources.finding: Seagrass carbon credit revenue varies by management approach

sources.citation: Oreska MPJ et al. 2020. Scientific Reports
sources.finding: Net GHG offset from seagrass restoration

axioms.name: mangrove_restoration_bcr
axioms.description: Mangrove restoration yields positive benefit-cost ratios
axioms.pattern: IF restoration_investment_usd(Site, I) AND discount_rate(R) THEN bcr(Site, f(I, R))

bcr_range.extraction_note: BCR range 6.35-15.0 from Zeng et al. 2025. Midpoint 10.68 as mode.

sources.citation: Zeng Y et al. 2025. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Optimal mangrove restoration investment strategies

axioms.name: kelp_forest_global_value
axioms.description: Kelp forests provide substantial ecosystem services globally
axioms.pattern: IF kelp_forest_area_ha(Site, A) THEN ecosystem_service_value_usd_yr(Site, A * V_ha)

global_value_usd_billion_yr.extraction_note: From Eger et al. 2023. Bounds estimated at +/-30% based on per-hectare value range.

value_per_ha_yr_range_usd.extraction_note: Range $64,400-$147,100/ha/yr from paper. Midpoint $105,750 as central estimate.

sources.citation: Eger AM et al. 2023. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Global kelp forest ecosystem service valuation

axioms.name: mpa_climate_resilience
axioms.description: MPAs enhance ecosystem resilience to climate disturbances
axioms.pattern: IF mpa_type(Site, 'no_take') THEN climate_resilience_multiplier(Site, 1.2)

kelp_recovery_premium_percent.extraction_note: 8.5% from Ortiz-Villa et al. 2024 California MPA study. Bounds estimated from cross-site variation.

coral_stability_increase_percent.extraction_note: Range 21-38% from Mellin et al. 2016. Midpoint 30% as mode.

coral_disturbance_impact_reduction_perce.extraction_note: Bounds estimated at +/-50% around point estimate.

sources.citation: Ortiz-Villa A et al. 2024. Global Change Biology
sources.finding: California MPAs show 8.5% kelp increase post-heatwave

sources.citation: Mellin C et al. 2016. Ecology Letters
sources.finding: MPAs increase coral reef community resilience by 21-38%

axioms.name: reef_degradation_fisheries_loss
axioms.description: Coral reef structural degradation reduces fisheries productivity
axioms.pattern: IF structural_complexity_loss(Site, X%) THEN fisheries_productivity_loss(Site, ~X%)

productivity_loss_at_degradation_percent.extraction_note: 35% from Rogers et al. 2018, with stated range 25-50%. Direct from paper.

fisheries_value_per_ha_yr_usd.extraction_note: Baseline coral reef fisheries value per ha per year (~$200/ha/yr). Derived from global coral reef fisheries value estimates ($6.8B/yr across ~284,000 km2 = ~$239/ha/yr; conservative central estimate $200/ha/yr accounting for site-level variability). Consistent with Cesar et al. fisheries ESV transfer literature.

sources.citation: Rogers A et al. 2018. Journal of Applied Ecology
sources.finding: Reef degradation causes 25-50% fisheries productivity loss

axioms.name: seagrass_carbon_sequestration_rate
axioms.description: Seagrass meadows sequester atmospheric CO2 through photosynthetic fixation and long-term burial of organic carbon in anoxic sediment soils
axioms.pattern: IF seagrass_area_ha(Site, A) AND seagrass_condition(Site, C) THEN carbon_sequestration_tCO2_yr(Site, A * rate * C)

sequestration_rate_tCO2_ha_yr.extraction_note: Conservative estimate for verified carbon credit projects. Natural gross sequestration can exceed 4 tCO2/ha/yr. Value accounts for additionality, leakage, and buffer deductions per VCS methodology. Lognormal distribution supported by right-skewed carbon stock data across 2700+ cores (Krause et al. 2025).

gross_npp_kg_C_ha_yr.extraction_note: Mean 5833 +/- 557 kg C/ha/yr from global synthesis of seagrass biomass and production data.

burial_efficiency_fraction.extraction_note: Approximately 20% of NPP is buried in seagrass sediment contributing to long-term sequestration. Varies with environmental and geomorphological conditions.

soil_carbon_stock_Mg_Corg_ha_top30cm_med.extraction_note: Median with IQR from global synthesis of 2700+ seagrass soil cores. 27% lower than previous global estimates.

caveats: Sequestration rates vary up to 800-fold across seagrass species and bioregions
Conservative credit-eligible rate (0.84 tCO2/ha/yr) is substantially below natural gross sequestration
Lognormal distribution reflects right-skewed global data driven by high-stock Mediterranean Posidonia meadows
Burial efficiency varies with hydrodynamic regime, sediment type, and geomorphological setting
30-50% of seagrass NPP is exported to adjacent habitats and not captured in local accounting

sources.citation: Gomis E et al. 2025. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Global seagrass NPP of 5,833 +/- 557 kg C/ha/yr; ~20% buried in sediment for long-term storage

sources.citation: Krause JR et al. 2025. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Median global seagrass soil Corg stock 24.2 Mg/ha (IQR 12.4-44.9) in top 30cm from 2700+ cores

sources.citation: Strydom S et al. 2023. Earth System Science Data
sources.finding: Global dataset on seagrass meadow structure, biomass, and production across 14,271 data points from 390 publications

example_calculation.interpretation: 100 ha healthy seagrass meadow sequesters ~84 tCO2/yr (range 40-180 tCO2/yr)

axioms.name: carbon_stock_to_credit_value
axioms.description: Seagrass carbon sequestration generates revenue through voluntary carbon credit markets, with prices reflecting credit quality and blue carbon premium
axioms.pattern: IF sequestration_tCO2_yr(Site, S) AND credit_price_usd(Market, P) THEN annual_credit_revenue_usd(Site, S * P)

price_per_tCO2_usd.extraction_note: Central estimate $30/tCO2 based on S&P Global Platts DBC-1 blue carbon benchmark at $29.30/tCO2e (Aug 2025 record). Range $15-50 reflects voluntary carbon market stratification by credit quality (high-quality credits average $14.80, premium blue carbon commands higher prices).

conservation_100ha_max_revenue_usd_10yr.extraction_note: Maximum 10-year revenue for 100ha seagrass conservation project from Duarte et al. 2025. Bounds estimated from project type variation.

net_offset_tCO2e_ha_yr.extraction_note: Net GHG offset from seagrass restoration, accounting for CH4 and N2O fluxes. From Oreska et al. 2020. Bounds estimated at +/-50% from site-level variation.

caveats: Carbon credit prices are volatile and vary by market, standard, and credit vintage
Blue carbon commands a premium over average VCM credits due to co-benefits (biodiversity, coastal protection)
Revenue projections assume successful project validation under VM0033 or equivalent methodology
Transaction costs, verification fees, and buffer pool deductions reduce net revenue
Net offset rate (0.42 tCO2e/ha/yr) accounts for CH4 and N2O counter-fluxes from seagrass sediments

sources.citation: Duarte CM et al. 2025. npj Ocean Sustainability
sources.finding: Seagrass carbon credit revenue varies $198-$15,337/ha by management approach; conservation of 100ha yields up to $1.53M over 10 years

sources.citation: Oreska MPJ et al. 2020. Scientific Reports
sources.finding: Net GHG offset from seagrass restoration is 0.42 tCO2e/ha/yr after accounting for CH4 and N2O

axioms.name: habitat_loss_carbon_emission
axioms.description: Seagrass habitat loss exposes stored sediment carbon to oxic conditions, causing remineralization and CO2 emissions that can be quantified as an emission factor per hectare lost
axioms.pattern: IF seagrass_loss_ha(Site, L) AND remineralization_fraction(F) THEN emission_tCO2(Site, L * stock_per_ha * F)

emission_factor_tCO2_per_ha.extraction_note: Derived from top-meter soil carbon stock (~140 Mg C/ha = 520 tCO2/ha) with variable remineralization fractions (10-50% per Arias-Ortiz et al. 2018, 53% per Krause et al. 2025). Low bound: 520 * 0.22 = 112; high bound: 520 * 0.92 = 476. Central estimate 294 represents ~57% remineralization. Triangular distribution reflects asymmetric uncertainty in remineralization rates.

soil_carbon_stock_top1m_tCO2_ha.extraction_note: ~140 Mg C/ha * 3.67 = 520 tCO2/ha for seagrass soils in top meter. Range reflects variability across plant functional groups and coastal settings.

remineralization_fraction.extraction_note: 53% remineralization over 25 years from Krause et al. 2025 empirically-derived formula. Arias-Ortiz et al. 2018 used 10-50% range for Shark Bay. Wider range reflects diverse disturbance scenarios.

global_at_risk_emissions_Tg_CO2.extraction_note: Total global seagrass carbon at risk if no conservation action taken. Social cost $213 billion (2020 USD).

caveats: Emission magnitude depends on disturbance type (dredging vs. heatwave vs. eutrophication)
Remineralization occurs over years to decades, not instantaneously
Direct physical disturbances (dredging) have larger per-area emission impacts than gradual warming
Hydrodynamic conditions strongly influence whether disturbed carbon is remineralized or reburied
Shark Bay 2010/2011 heatwave case: 36% of meadow damaged, 2-9 Tg CO2 released over 3 years

sources.citation: Arias-Ortiz A et al. 2018. Nature Climate Change
sources.finding: Marine heatwave drove 2-9 Tg CO2 release from Shark Bay seagrass (36% meadow loss, 10-50% remineralization)

sources.citation: Krause JR et al. 2025. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Global seagrass carbon at risk: 1,154 Tg CO2 (665-1699); 53% remineralization over 25 years; social cost $213B

example_calculation.interpretation: Loss of 1,000 ha seagrass could release ~294,000 tCO2 (range 112,000-476,000 tCO2)

axioms.name: mpa_protection_carbon_permanence
axioms.description: MPA designation and enforcement reduce permanence risk for blue carbon stocks by mitigating direct anthropogenic threats, though climate-driven risks persist
axioms.pattern: IF mpa_type(Site, 'no_take') AND enforced(Site, TRUE) THEN permanence_years(Site, P) AND risk_reduction(direct_threats, R)

permanence_years.extraction_note: Central estimate 50 years based on VCS crediting period norms and MPA governance timescales. Low bound 25 years reflects minimum viable crediting period. High bound 100 years reflects well-governed long-term MPAs. Lovelock et al. 2025 found 85% of SE Asian mangroves face permanence risks from socioeconomic and climate factors.

socioeconomic_risk_fraction.extraction_note: 85% of SE Asian mangroves face permanence risks from oil palm, rice, and aquaculture conversion pressure. Bounds estimated from regional variation.

climate_risk_heatwave_loss_fraction.extraction_note: 36% of Shark Bay seagrass damaged by 2010/2011 marine heatwave. Bounds reflect range of heatwave severity scenarios.

caveats: MPA designation mitigates direct threats (dredging, development) but not climate-driven threats (heatwaves, sea-level rise)
Permanence is a key risk for blue carbon credit viability - buffer pools required
85% of SE Asian coastal ecosystems face permanence risks despite protection status
Crediting periods should match governance stability and climate projections
Diverse funding sources needed beyond carbon credits to maintain long-term conservation viability

sources.citation: Lovelock CE et al. 2025. Communications Earth & Environment
sources.finding: Permanence risks affect 85% of SE Asian mangroves; socioeconomic and climate risks limit blue carbon financing viability

sources.citation: Duarte CM et al. 2025. npj Ocean Sustainability
sources.finding: Management approach determines seagrass recovery and carbon mitigation outcomes; long-term protection essential for permanence

example_calculation.interpretation: Well-governed no-take MPA provides ~50-year carbon permanence (range 25-100 years), requiring buffer pool for climate risk

axioms.name: mangrove_carbon_sequestration_rate
axioms.description: Mangrove ecosystems sequester atmospheric carbon at high annual rates through biomass accumulation and sediment burial
axioms.pattern: IF mangrove_area_ha(Site, A) AND mangrove_condition(Site, C) THEN carbon_sequestration_tCO2_yr(Site, A * rate * C)

sequestration_rate_tCO2_ha_yr.extraction_note: Derived from Donato et al. 2011 carbon density data and Murdiyarso et al. 2023 emission factors. Range reflects high variability across mangrove types and geomorphic settings.

aboveground_sequestration_fraction.extraction_note: From Alongi 2014 review of mangrove carbon cycling. Approximately 30% in aboveground biomass, 70% belowground.

sources.citation: Donato DC et al. 2011. Nature Geoscience
sources.finding: Mangroves store 1,023 Mg C/ha in undisturbed state, among most carbon-rich forests globally

sources.citation: Murdiyarso D et al. 2023. Carbon Balance Management
sources.finding: Indonesian mangrove sequestration rates by condition class

sources.citation: Alongi DM. 2014. Annual Review of Marine Science
sources.finding: Comprehensive review of mangrove carbon cycling and storage dynamics

example_calculation.interpretation: 100 ha healthy mangrove sequesters ~640 tCO2/yr (range 210-1,080 tCO2/yr)

axioms.name: kelp_carbon_export
axioms.description: Kelp forests export dissolved and particulate organic carbon to the deep ocean via DOC/POC pathways, contributing to long-term carbon sequestration
axioms.pattern: IF kelp_forest_area_ha(Site, A) THEN carbon_export_tC_yr(Site, A * export_rate)

carbon_export_rate_tC_ha_yr.extraction_note: From Krause-Jensen & Duarte 2016. Macroalgae export 0.34 tC/ha/yr to deep ocean via DOC/POC. Range reflects variability in export efficiency by current regime and depth.

sequestration_efficiency_percent.extraction_note: 11% of macroalgal NPP reaches the deep sea for long-term sequestration. Bounds from uncertainty in export pathways.

sources.citation: Krause-Jensen D & Duarte CM. 2016. Nature Geoscience
sources.finding: Macroalgae contribute substantially to marine carbon sequestration via deep ocean export

sources.citation: Wilson KL et al. 2025. Science Advances
sources.finding: Pathways of blue carbon export from kelp and seagrass beds along Atlantic coast

example_calculation.interpretation: 1,000 ha kelp forest exports ~340 tC/yr to deep ocean (range 100-680 tC/yr)

axioms.name: salt_marsh_carbon_sequestration
axioms.description: Salt marshes sequester atmospheric carbon through annual burial in waterlogged sediments, creating long-term carbon sinks
axioms.pattern: IF salt_marsh_area_ha(Site, A) AND condition(Site, C) THEN carbon_sequestration_tCO2_yr(Site, A * rate * C)

sequestration_rate_tCO2_ha_yr.extraction_note: From Howard et al. 2017 blue carbon primer. Salt marsh burial rates 0.9-3.8 tCO2/ha/yr depending on latitude and sediment supply.

sources.citation: Howard J et al. 2017. Frontiers in Ecology
sources.finding: Clarifying the role of coastal systems in climate mitigation; salt marsh sequestration rates

sources.citation: McLeod E et al. 2011. Frontiers in Ecology
sources.finding: Blueprint for blue carbon: role of vegetated coastal habitats as carbon sinks

example_calculation.interpretation: 100 ha salt marsh sequesters ~210 tCO2/yr (range 90-380 tCO2/yr)

axioms.name: blue_carbon_additionality
axioms.description: Carbon credit projects must demonstrate additionality - the difference between project sequestration and counterfactual baseline
axioms.pattern: IF project_sequestration_tCO2(Site, S) AND baseline_sequestration_tCO2(Site, B) THEN creditable_tCO2(Site, (S - B) * additionality_rate)

additionality_rate.extraction_note: 40-60% additionality rate for blue carbon projects. Range reflects project type variation (conservation vs restoration) from Duarte et al. 2025.

sources.citation: Duarte CM et al. 2025. npj Ocean Sustainability
sources.finding: Management approach determines seagrass recovery and carbon mitigation outcomes; additionality varies by project type

sources.citation: Lovelock CE et al. 2019. Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution
sources.finding: Blue carbon management challenges including additionality verification

axioms.name: carbon_permanence_discount
axioms.description: Blue carbon credits require buffer pool deductions to account for reversibility risk from natural and anthropogenic disturbances
axioms.pattern: IF gross_credits_tCO2(Site, G) AND risk_profile(Site, R) THEN net_credits_tCO2(Site, G * (1 - buffer_rate))

buffer_pool_fraction.extraction_note: 10-25% buffer pool deduction for blue carbon projects. Range reflects VCS/Verra methodology requirements and site-specific risk profiles from Lovelock et al. 2025.

sources.citation: Lovelock CE et al. 2025. Communications Earth & Environment
sources.finding: Permanence risks affect 85% of SE Asian mangroves; buffer pool requirements vary by risk profile

sources.citation: Oreska MPJ et al. 2020. Scientific Reports
sources.finding: Net GHG offset accounting requires deductions for non-permanence risk

axioms.name: carbon_price_sensitivity
axioms.description: Ecosystem service value from blue carbon is highly sensitive to voluntary carbon market price fluctuations
axioms.pattern: IF sequestration_tCO2_yr(Site, S) AND carbon_price_usd(Market, P) THEN esv_sensitivity(Site, S * dP/P)

price_range_usd_per_tCO2.extraction_note: VCM price range $5-50/tCO2. Central estimate $30 based on S&P Global Platts DBC-1 blue carbon benchmark. Low end reflects low-quality credits; high end reflects premium blue carbon with co-benefits.

esv_elasticity_to_price.extraction_note: Near-unit elasticity: carbon ESV scales approximately linearly with credit price. Slight deviations from transaction cost structure.

sources.citation: Duarte CM et al. 2025. npj Ocean Sustainability
sources.finding: Seagrass carbon credit revenue varies dramatically with market price and project type

axioms.name: coral_reef_wave_attenuation_coefficient
axioms.description: Coral reef structural complexity determines wave energy reduction, with species composition and reef depth modulating attenuation efficiency
axioms.pattern: IF reef_condition(Site, C) AND reef_depth_m(Site, D) THEN wave_energy_reduction_percent(Site, f(C, D))

wave_energy_reduction_healthy_percent.extraction_note: 97% wave energy reduction for healthy reef from Beck et al. 2018 and Ferrario et al. 2014 meta-analysis. Represents intact reef crest and flats.

wave_energy_reduction_degraded_percent.extraction_note: Degraded reef attenuation from flattening and loss of structural complexity. Wider uncertainty reflects variable degradation states.

depth_sensitivity_percent_per_10cm.extraction_note: 2% change in flood risk per 10cm reef depth change from Beck et al. 2018 sensitivity analysis.

sources.citation: Beck MW et al. 2018. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Coral reefs provide $272B/yr flood protection; 97% wave energy reduction for healthy reefs

sources.citation: Reguero BG et al. 2025. Science Advances
sources.finding: Hybrid coral reef restoration provides cost-effective coastal protection

axioms.name: mangrove_storm_surge_reduction
axioms.description: Mangrove forests attenuate storm surge height as water passes through the root and canopy structure, with reduction proportional to mangrove width
axioms.pattern: IF mangrove_width_km(Site, W) AND storm_category(Event, Cat) THEN surge_reduction_cm(Site, W * rate)

surge_reduction_cm_per_km.extraction_note: 5-50 cm/km storm surge reduction from Montgomery et al. 2019. Central estimate 20 cm/km for typical mangrove density. Wide range reflects variation in forest structure and storm intensity.

protection_value_usd_per_km_per_yr.extraction_note: Per-km protection value derived from Menendez et al. 2020 global flood protection model. Range from cross-regional variation.

sources.citation: Montgomery JM et al. 2019. Geophysical Research Letters
sources.finding: Attenuation of storm surges by coastal mangroves: 5-50 cm/km depending on forest structure

sources.citation: Menendez P et al. 2020. Scientific Reports
sources.finding: Mangroves provide >$65B/yr global flood protection; 15M additional people at risk without mangroves

axioms.name: seagrass_sediment_stabilization
axioms.description: Seagrass meadows stabilize coastal sediments through root binding and wave dampening, preventing erosion and reducing turbidity
axioms.pattern: IF seagrass_area_ha(Site, A) AND seagrass_density(Site, D) THEN erosion_prevention_value_usd_yr(Site, A * V_ha)

erosion_prevention_value_usd_ha_yr.extraction_note: Range $2,500-15,000/ha/yr from Ondiviela et al. 2025 wave attenuation review and Nordlund et al. 2023 services review. Central estimate geometric mean.

wave_attenuation_percent.extraction_note: Seagrass wave attenuation 20-70% depending on meadow density and species. From comprehensive review by Ondiviela et al. 2025.

sources.citation: Ondiviela B et al. 2025. Frontiers in Marine Science
sources.finding: Comprehensive review quantifying wave attenuation by seagrass: 20-70% reduction depending on meadow characteristics

sources.citation: Nordlund LM et al. 2023. Hydrobiologia
sources.finding: Review of seagrass ecosystem services including sediment stabilization and erosion prevention

axioms.name: reef_insurance_trigger_value
axioms.description: Parametric insurance products for coral reefs use wind speed or wave height thresholds to trigger rapid restoration funding after storm damage
axioms.pattern: IF wind_speed_kmh(Event, W) AND W > threshold THEN insurance_payout(Site, P) AND restoration_funding(Site, P * coverage_rate)

wind_speed_trigger_kmh.extraction_note: Wind speed >130 km/h typical trigger for reef insurance products, based on Mesoamerican Reef Insurance program and Reguero et al. 2025 hybrid restoration economics.

average_payout_usd_per_event.extraction_note: Typical payout range based on Mesoamerican Reef Insurance program. Actual payouts vary by coverage area and storm severity.

sources.citation: Reguero BG et al. 2025. Science Advances
sources.finding: Hybrid coral reef restoration provides cost-effective nature-based coastal protection

sources.citation: Lumbroso D et al. 2025. Journal of Flood Risk Management
sources.finding: Quantifying flood risk reduction of coastal nature-based solutions in the Caribbean

axioms.name: mpa_spillover_fisheries_value
axioms.description: Biomass accumulation within MPAs generates spillover of adult fish and larval export to adjacent fishing grounds, increasing catches beyond MPA boundaries
axioms.pattern: IF mpa_biomass_ratio(Site, R) AND mpa_boundary_km(Site, B) THEN adjacent_catch_multiplier(Site, f(R, B))

adjacent_catch_increase_multiplier.extraction_note: 1.5-3x catch increase in areas adjacent to well-managed MPAs. Central estimate 2x from Hopf et al. 2024 and spillover literature. Range reflects MPA age, size, and habitat connectivity.

spillover_distance_km.extraction_note: Effective spillover distance 1-15 km depending on species mobility and habitat continuity. From Edgar et al. 2014 NEOLI analysis.

sources.citation: Hopf JK et al. 2024. Ecological Applications
sources.finding: No-take MPAs show 6.7x biomass inside, with significant spillover to adjacent areas

sources.citation: Edgar GJ et al. 2014. Nature
sources.finding: NEOLI features determine MPA effectiveness and spillover potential

sources.citation: Gaines SD et al. 2010. PNAS
sources.finding: Designing marine reserve networks for both conservation and fisheries management

axioms.name: marine_ecotourism_elasticity
axioms.description: Visitor willingness-to-pay for marine ecotourism is elastic to ecosystem condition, declining as coral cover, fish abundance, or water clarity decrease
axioms.pattern: IF coral_cover_loss_percent(Site, L) THEN wtp_decline_percent(Site, f(L))

wtp_decline_per_10pct_coral_loss_percent.extraction_note: 15-30% WTP decline per 10% coral cover loss from Wolff et al. 2022 Maui study and Spalding et al. 2017. Central estimate 22% as midpoint.

minimum_coral_cover_for_tourism_percent.extraction_note: Below 10-30% coral cover, tourism appeal drops precipitously. From Spalding et al. 2017 global tourism mapping.

sources.citation: Wolff NH et al. 2022. Ecological Economics
sources.finding: Climate change impacts on coral reef economic value in Maui; WTP sensitivity to reef condition

sources.citation: Spalding M et al. 2017. Marine Policy
sources.finding: Global coral reef tourism value mapped; $36B/yr dependent on reef condition

axioms.name: coral_bleaching_tourism_loss
axioms.description: Coral bleaching events driven by thermal stress reduce reef tourism revenue proportionally to bleaching severity and duration
axioms.pattern: IF degree_heating_weeks(Site, DHW) THEN tourism_revenue_decline_percent(Site, f(DHW))

revenue_decline_per_dhw_percent.extraction_note: 3-12% revenue decline per degree-heating-week from Wolff et al. 2022 Maui analysis and broader bleaching-tourism literature. Central estimate 7%.

recovery_time_years_mild.extraction_note: Mild bleaching recovery 2-5 years from Hughes et al. 2018 spatial/temporal bleaching patterns.

recovery_time_years_severe.extraction_note: Severe bleaching recovery 7-15 years. Some reefs may not recover to pre-bleaching state.

sources.citation: Wolff NH et al. 2022. Ecological Economics
sources.finding: Bleaching-driven tourism revenue loss in Maui proportional to thermal stress

sources.citation: Hughes TP et al. 2018. Science
sources.finding: Spatial and temporal patterns of mass coral bleaching in the Anthropocene

axioms.name: species_richness_insurance_value
axioms.description: Higher species richness acts as biological insurance, reducing portfolio risk by buffering ecosystem service delivery against environmental variability
axioms.pattern: IF species_richness_increase_percent(Site, R) THEN risk_reduction_percent(Site, f(R))

risk_reduction_per_10pct_richness_increa.extraction_note: 8-15% risk reduction per 10% species richness increase. Derived from Edgar et al. 2014 finding that biodiversity-rich MPAs show more stable ecosystem services. Central estimate 11%.

functional_redundancy_threshold_species.extraction_note: Minimum species count for functional redundancy that provides insurance effect. Varies by functional group composition.

sources.citation: Edgar GJ et al. 2014. Nature
sources.finding: Biodiversity-rich MPAs show more stable ecosystem service delivery over time

sources.citation: Cinner JE et al. 2016. Nature
sources.finding: Bright spots among coral reefs linked to biodiversity-driven resilience

axioms.name: debt_for_nature_swap_ratio
axioms.description: Sovereign debt-for-nature swaps convert distressed government debt into conservation funding at discounted rates, generating fiscal space for marine protection
axioms.pattern: IF sovereign_debt_face_value(Country, D) AND discount_rate(Swap, R) THEN conservation_funding(Country, D * R * commitment_fraction)

debt_discount_fraction.extraction_note: 30-50% discount on face value typical for debt-for-nature swaps. Grounded in Seychelles restructured debt case evidence (Booth and Brooks 2023) and broader conservation finance literature.

conservation_commitment_fraction.extraction_note: 15-50% of swap proceeds committed to conservation activities. Seychelles debt restructuring implementation reports a 30% EEZ protection commitment (Booth and Brooks 2023).

sources.citation: Booth M and Brooks CM. 2023. Frontiers in Marine Science
sources.finding: Seychelles debt restructuring case study documents governance design, funding streams, and marine conservation commitments in debt-for-nature implementation

sources.citation: Sumaila UR et al. 2021. One Earth
sources.finding: Ocean finance mechanisms including debt-for-nature swaps for sustainable ocean economy

axioms.name: blue_bond_coupon_premium
axioms.description: Blue bonds may trade at a small yield premium (greenium) compared to conventional bonds due to investor demand for sustainable ocean finance
axioms.pattern: IF bond_face_value(Instrument, V) AND greenium_bps(Market, G) THEN annual_cost_savings(Instrument, V * G / 10000)

greenium_basis_points.extraction_note: 2-15 bps greenium for blue/green bonds from Wang et al. 2023 and Tucker et al. 2022. Central estimate 8 bps as midpoint. Market still developing with limited issuances.

typical_issuance_size_usd_million.extraction_note: Blue bond issuances range from $10M (sovereign first issuances) to $500M (development bank instruments). From Tucker et al. 2022.

sources.citation: Wang Z et al. 2023. Journal of Risk and Financial Management
sources.finding: Blue bond market as catalyst for ocean financing; greenium analysis

sources.citation: Tucker A et al. 2022. Marine Policy
sources.finding: Blue bonds status, trends, and insights for marine conservation finance

axioms.name: ecosystem_restoration_roi
axioms.description: Active ecosystem restoration generates measurable return on investment through recovered ecosystem services, with benefit-cost ratios varying by habitat type
axioms.pattern: IF restoration_cost_usd(Site, C) AND habitat_type(Site, H) THEN bcr(Site, f(H, C))

bcr_mangrove.extraction_note: Mangrove restoration BCR 6.35-15x from Zeng et al. 2025. Highest BCR among coastal habitats.

bcr_coral.extraction_note: Coral restoration BCR 3-8x from Reguero et al. 2025 and Bayraktarov et al. 2016. Includes hybrid restoration approaches.

bcr_seagrass.extraction_note: Seagrass restoration BCR 2-7x from Orth et al. 2020. Varies with restoration method and site conditions.

sources.citation: Zeng Y et al. 2025. Nature Communications
sources.finding: Mangrove restoration BCR 6.35-15x; optimal investment generates $231-725B net ESV gain over 20 years

sources.citation: Bayraktarov E et al. 2016. Ecological Applications
sources.finding: Cost and feasibility of marine coastal restoration across habitat types

sources.citation: Orth RJ et al. 2020. Science Advances
sources.finding: Seagrass restoration leads to rapid recovery of coastal ecosystem services

axioms.name: mpa_network_connectivity_bonus
axioms.description: Networks of connected MPAs provide greater portfolio-level value than isolated reserves through larval connectivity, adult spillover, and risk diversification
axioms.pattern: IF mpa_network_size(Network, N) AND connectivity_index(Network, C) THEN portfolio_value_bonus_percent(Network, f(N, C))

portfolio_value_increase_percent.extraction_note: 15-30% portfolio value increase from network connectivity. From Gaines et al. 2010 network design optimization and connectivity modeling literature.

minimum_network_size_sites.extraction_note: Minimum 3-10 connected sites for meaningful network benefits. From network design literature.

sources.citation: Gaines SD et al. 2010. PNAS
sources.finding: MPA network design optimization for conservation and fisheries; connectivity increases total value

sources.citation: Holstein DM et al. 2015. PLOS ONE
sources.finding: Coral reef connectivity data informs regional MPA network design

sources.citation: Cowen RK et al. 2009. Annual Review of Marine Science
sources.finding: Larval dispersal and population connectivity in marine systems

axioms.name: climate_adaptation_avoided_cost
axioms.description: Ecosystem-based adaptation avoids future infrastructure costs by using natural capital for coastal defense, with benefit-cost ratios comparing EbA to grey infrastructure
axioms.pattern: IF eba_investment_usd(Site, I) AND grey_alternative_usd(Site, G) THEN bcr(Site, G / I)

eba_bcr.extraction_note: BCR 2-10x for ecosystem-based adaptation vs grey infrastructure. From Lumbroso et al. 2025 Caribbean NBS analysis and broader EbA literature. Central estimate 5x.

cost_savings_percent_vs_grey.extraction_note: 30-80% cost savings for EbA vs equivalent grey infrastructure. From Gattuso et al. 2018 ocean solutions review. Wide range reflects site-specific conditions.

sources.citation: Lumbroso D et al. 2025. Journal of Flood Risk Management
sources.finding: Coastal NBS in Caribbean provide BCR 2-10x compared to grey infrastructure alternatives

sources.citation: Gattuso JP et al. 2018. Frontiers in Marine Science
sources.finding: Ocean solutions to address climate change; EbA cost-effectiveness analysis

sources.citation: Roberts CM et al. 2017. PNAS
sources.finding: Marine reserves can mitigate and promote adaptation to climate change

usage_guidance.confidence_propagation: When chaining multiple axioms, multiply confidence intervals
usage_guidance.uncertainty_handling: Always report ranges, not point estimates
usage_guidance.source_verification: Cross-reference with source DOIs before using in financial context

uncertainty_types.research_grounded: CI derived from source paper data (tables, figures, or stated ranges)
uncertainty_types.estimated_uncertainty: CI estimated from methodology (e.g., +/-20% transfer error, proportional scaling). Flagged for future refinement with primary literature.
